stories.text:
Hi HN. I'm a 49 yo in an emergent economy country. I've been working for 26 years in the same company, a ~200 emp. regional leader in it's core business.

Since 2011 I've got a remuneration which is tied to the price of the base main service the company provides, so my salary has been the same but my income has increased as the price of this particular service varied with the years. I've got no other benefits beyond the granted by working law in this country (vacations, etc.). My salary is roughly 10-12x the base salary of a non-professional employee, and 3x the median IT & Telco salary in the country, although I live and work on a second tier city of ~1M people, so perhaps 3.5-4x the median here.

The company has grown and expanded it's businesses since I've entered at an early stage and I was instrumental in every aspect of the company development (modulo finances) implementing most of the processes and operations that are running the company to this day; for example, but not limited to: implementation of core technical procedures, develop of administrative and CRM software, main mission critical service software, security, communication networks deployment and integration (from analog RF to mesh network), fleet tracking and location (AVL) with driver registration, maps and dispatch, several mobile apps for internal use (tech/support staff, sales team, etc.), main app for customers, networking, communications and IT installations in several buildings, sysadmin, DB admin, a myriad of other tasks from key strategy and technology selection and deployment for multi million dollar projects to problem resolution in every technical concern, while also providing support in a very demanding 24/7 environment. Much of this was made by myself up to 2013, since then I've lead a small team of developers and technical staff. I'm generally responsible for the whole operation running smoothly 24/7 (main business is 24/7 service).

I think I'm not being payed adequately for my work and the value I've made for the company through the years. I have a very good and friendly relation with one of the owners (nominally my boss), and I'm about to open a negotiation with him about this.

I think the company will offer me some money (not more than 10% increase over my base salary) and some promise for the future tied to some diffuse and subjective metric of their own, which I will reject as a matter of course.

What do you think will be my best strategy from that point on? It's possible that my strongest point is that there are no one person that can take over if I left, so they would need to get two to three people. There are key security implications on this scenario too.

I need the work to support my family, and with my savings and my spouse income I could live perhaps for one to two years educing our expenditure; there are some difficult decisions to be made in this regard too, like firing our domestic employee of 12 years, not going on vacations with the kids, no upgrading our cars or selling some property, etc.

I have a little side project but it's not enough money and I'm not sure if it can success. Thanks a lot.
stories.title: Salary Re-Negotiation Strategy

stories.text:
I posted something to Show HN earlier today and my analytics dashboard (Simple Analytics) tells me that ⅔ of the visits are direct / no referrer.

At first I though they must be running in Incognito/Private mode, but I tested Chrome/Firefox/Safari and they all still send the referer in the request header even in Incognito/Private mode, which seems odd to me as that would be an easy thing to hide.

So what would cause this? Ad blockers? Corporate firewalls and proxies? Or are ⅔ of you copying and pasting the links on HN instead of just clicking?
stories.title: Ask HN: What is blocking referer headers?
